briefing.opening: Hello everyone. I will now begin the climate briefing for January 16, 2026. Today, as warnings continue globally regarding the severity of the climate crisis and its socioeconomic impacts, various efforts for climate change adaptation and carbon neutrality have been reported both domestically and internationally.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis: 'New Normal' and Economic Burden
sections.content: According to major reports released today, extreme heatwaves and torrential rains have now become the 'new normal,' and a serious warning has been issued that the breakdown of the 1.5-degree climate threshold has become entrenched [5, 25]. Notably, 2025 is projected to be the third hottest year on record [84, 97, 101], and these climate changes are nearly doubling ocean damage, exacerbating economic costs [87, 107]. In the United States, research has revealed a 12% decrease in income due to climate change [88, 91, 92, 115], and the possibility of a 14% reduction in sports industry revenue by 2030 has also been raised [108], indicating the profound impact of the climate crisis on the overall socioeconomic system.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Domestic Climate Change Adaptation and Proactive Response in the Agricultural Sector
sections.content: Domestic local governments are intensifying efforts to proactively respond to climate change. Specifically, Gijang-gun has initiated proactive management of crop pests and diseases [1, 2, 3, 11, 13, 14, 18, 21], and Haman-gun is also addressing labor shortages and climate change through the establishment of advanced smart farms [4, 20, 23]. In addition, Wonju City has completed its final report on urban climate change disaster vulnerability analysis [6, 8, 26], strengthening the region's disaster response capabilities, and Seogwipo City is working to prevent climate change damage through the modernization of aquaculture facilities [12], demonstrating active and concrete movements for climate change adaptation across the agricultural and broader community sectors [9, 10, 16, 105].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Efforts Towards a Carbon-Neutral Society
sections.content: Domestic industries and local governments are pursuing diverse efforts to achieve carbon neutrality. KEPCO KPS has announced plans to intensively invest this year's budget of 2.0252 trillion KRW in AI, safety, and carbon neutrality sectors [28, 29, 30, 35, 41, 42, 44, 45, 47, 48, 49, 57, 58], which is particularly noteworthy given the increasing pressure on industries, alongside the forecast that 2026 will be a critical juncture for the 'actual transition' to carbon neutrality [38]. Furthermore, the Korea City Gas Association is preparing for the era of carbon neutrality through hydrogen blending and E-methane initiatives [34, 55], and the Korea Petroleum Management Institute is also contributing to establishing distribution order and achieving carbon neutrality [33, 50, 59]. At the local government level, various policies are being promoted to encourage citizen participation, such as Wonju City's winter break carbon neutrality experience program [31, 36, 61], Daejeon Seo-gu's carbon neutrality practice apartment competition [32, 46, 53, 56], and Geoje City's initiative to link carbon neutrality points when applying for electric and hydrogen vehicle subsidies [37, 39], among others [19, 27, 40, 43, 51, 52, 54, 60].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Renewable Energy Expansion, Policy Discussions and Challenges
sections.content: While renewable energy expansion is continuously being pursued, it faces several challenges in terms of policy direction and actual implementation. Amidst the inauguration of Choi Jae-kwan as the new chairman of the Korea Energy Agency, who pledged to expand renewable energy supply and foster the industry [63, 65, 74, 81], discussions on standard legislation are active, with strong opposition to including air-source heat pumps as renewable energy and related forums being held [62, 66, 72, 75]. While Korea Western Power has set a renewable energy target of 13.5 GW by 2040 [64], and Korea Midland Power is entering the Middle Eastern renewable energy market [76], with continuous corporate investment and business expansion [68, 69, 70, 71, 77, 78, 79, 82, 83, 116], the consecutive failures of offshore wind power projects in Ulsan point to a failure of renewable energy policies that were 'left solely to the market' [73], demonstrating the need for thorough review for stable implementation. Meanwhile, concerns have also been raised that Korea Hydro & Nuclear Power (KHNP)'s increased target for nuclear power plant utilization could hinder renewable energy expansion [80].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Community's Climate Change Awareness and Scientific Approaches
sections.content: In the international community, awareness and scientific approaches to climate change are actively progressing. Public interest persists, with Guernsey students expressing climate change concerns at an annual event [85], but research has also shown that public consensus on climate change does not significantly increase support for action [93, 95]. Meanwhile, efforts to understand the climate system through historical and scientific analysis continue, such as evaluating thousands of years of climate change using diatoms [89], and raising the possibility that climate change played a role in the fall of the Tang Dynasty [98, 112]. UC Irvine public health experts have pointed out nutritional disparities caused by climate change [90], and Colorado River experts have warned that some management strategies for water scarcity and climate change are insufficient [96], demonstrating active research on climate impacts in specific regions [94, 104, 105, 106, 109, 110, 111, 113]. Furthermore, discussions on how climate information is communicated are also notable, including calls to discontinue the use of the term 'climate change' [86] and NASA's release of global temperature data without mentioning 'climate change' [99], among others [102, 103, 114, 17].

briefing.closing: In today's briefing, the severity of the climate crisis was once again emphasized, and we were able to confirm various domestic and international adaptation and mitigation efforts to address it. Continuous scientific research and policy efforts will be crucial keys to overcoming the climate crisis. This concludes today's climate briefing.
